text: This video is brought to you by Dashlane.

Protect your passwords and make your online
life easier with the link in the description.

Let's say you are on a limited budget, trying
to build a PC to play games on...
In general, there are two approaches to this.

If you prefer new components and you want
to make upgrading easier in the future then

you use a budget option like the Athlon 200GE
of Ryzen 3 2200G...

and hopefully, I will be able to also recommend
a Pentium here if they released.

Or you can take one of the most popular suggestions
out there and look for a cheap used old PC
and add a "decent GPU".

This advice initially makes sense since the
GPU is generally what does most of the work

but considering the amount of CPU power modern
games are starting to use it is worth questioning

where the limits of this strategy currently
are.

After all, many of old cheap office or school
PCs that you can find for next to nothing

in Europe and especially in the developing
world use the ancient 775 sockets means for

stuff like core 2 duos which are rarely able
to run a recently released game, even with
conservative expectations.
This is a problem since

99% of the stuff that you can tweak or modify
on a game to increase performance is going

to affect GPU usage, so there is very little
that you can do if you hit a very strong CPU
bottleneck.

While that old motherboards can be modded
to run old server or workstation Xeons which

can game very well, I made a video experimenting
that,

I personally draw the line on first-generation
quad-core i5s and i7s.

A lot of people make the mistake of purely
judging an intel CPU by its i3, i5 or i7 label,
its number of core and its clock speed,

which leads to a lot of statements like i7s
being eternally high-end components but the
reality is a bit disappointing.

In super general terms, i3 is a label assigned
to entry-level, i5 to mid-tier and i7 to the
high end of a specific generation.

Since newer generations usually bring improvements
in power consumption and performance

often a newer i3 can outperform a really old
i7.

This statement is filled with asterisks and
exceptions of course because there is going

to be a ton of edge cases especially when
you add laptops CPUs.

With that said, older CPUs can still be quite
usable.

Up until two years ago my personal desktop
PC was powered by an ancient i5 750, the very
first i5 CPU released according to wikipedia.

I ended up changing it mid-2017 because I
needed something capable of streaming and

recording footage from a capture card simultaneously,
but at that time

I had started the i5 750 that it was having
trouble keeping over 30 fps on some of the
stuff I was trying.

But what if we stay roughly around the same
generation but try an i7 rather than an i5?

I recently came into possession of an interesting
set of parts.

6 gwigwobyetes﻿ of shinny DDR3 ram in triple
channel configuration, which is a thing I
had heard of but never seen,

an old Gigabyte motherboard with triple channel
RAM support which, again, is an interesting
oddity but most important an i7 950.

The 950 was the 4th i7 ever released, part
of the bloomfield family with a 45 nm lithography

process which looks enormous compared to what
current CPUs are built
with.

I got this all used for 50 euros, less than
the price of a single Athlon 200GE, and since

6 GB is the bare minimum I think I can get
away with for recently released titles that

mean that the only major components missing
for an interesting build were a cooler and
a GPU.

And that begged the question, was this a good
idea in the first place if I wanted to try
bigger games released somewhat recently?

I paired this with the cheapest compatible
cooler I could find in Amazon and a small

GTX 1050 that is pretty capable without requiring
extra power cables or a more competent Power
Supply and started experimenting!

The recently released Far Cry: New Dawn was
a good place to start since it includes a
pretty good benchmark tool.

Since my initial interest was to find the
limits of the CPU I dropped the resolution

and settings to the lowest they could and
then used the configuration file changes from

my video in the topic, linked in the corner
and description, to get the graphics to super
low levels and use as little GPU as possible.

The result was fantastic, with an average
of over 70 FPS and a minimum close to 60 it

is obvious that the GPU is the only real limit
on playing this game and that the old i7 can
easily keep up on low settings.

In fact, I raised the game to the regular
low settings and 1080p with 80% internal resolution

and this cheap PC is easily able to keep within
playable parameters both in the benchmark
and the game.

As you might notice like a lot of modern games
"low" setting looks pretty good and so you
can easily enjoy the game on this setup.

Now, a thing that you must keep in mind when
recycling old CPU is the occasional compatibility
pitfall.

Occasionally games will require newer instruction
sets that older CPUs lack, but thankfully

this i7 seems to include instruction set needed
by games like Apex, which is another softball
in terms of CPU requirements.

Even while jumping out of the ship, or flying
to a highly contested area the CPU is able

to keep up with the game at 60 FPS or more
without much trouble.
However, those game were softballs.

"Most" modern games running on a good engine
will behave this way with any reasonable quadcore

CPU doing its thing and the GPU doing most
of the heavy lifting.

I want to tackle the big exceptions, starting
with the more innocuous ones.

Modern Battlefield games running on the Frostbite
Engine tend to have much higher than average
CPU usage than many other games while on multiplayer.

Sure enough, a match on the Amsterdam map
on Battlefield 5 has significant slowdown

at the start while the map loads, which can
cause some unexpected freezes, and then continued

overall high CPU usage which nets an average
of around 35 FPS which can be enough or too
little depending on your expectations.

Granted, this is a case when it makes sense
for a lot of CPU usage given the number of

physic effect and players involved, not to
mention that our glorious 6 GB of RAM is used

to the limit but there are some other cases
that are a bit more irritating.

There is a constant large discussion on PC
Gaming spaces around the issue DMR.

Since piracy tends to be easier to pull off
on PC publishers tend to try and compensate

by using draconian measures of Digital Rights
Management to try and avoid the game getting
cracked in the first few weeks of release.

While my opinion on lowering a game's performance
or make it awfully inconvenient for the sake

of trying to prevent piracy on a limited window
is... beyond the scope of this video and likely
deserves and video of its own

the reality is that there is strong evidence
of some of the stronger DRM methods, like

the dreaded Denuvo, can have a strong impact
on CPU performance.

Devil May Cry 5 is one of the most notorious
cases, being one of the very few games when

we have access to both an executable with
Denuvo and one without it which is why articles
like this one spread like wildfire upon release.

Since the effect of this falls squarely on
the CPU and not the GPU most people are unlikely
to notice. Unless you are using and older or cheaper CPU.

Surprisingly, on the full denuvo version of
the game our old i7 has no problems.

The start of any level has a sharp spike on
CPU usage until the full thing loads, something

that tends to be common when using old CPUs
on modern games, but after that the game did

so well on the low settings that I was easily
able to lock the game to a 60 fps vsync and

play comfortably apart from some very occasional
microfreeze which are likely more about the
lack of ram than the CPU itself.

The real big test here is the latest Assassin's
Creed Games.

Now, there has been a lot of discussion regarding
the DRM of these games.

Experts on the cracking scene claim the bad
implementation of two separate DRM measures

causes massive CPU performance issues on the
game, something the Ubisoft denies.

While I do not nearly have the expertise to
claim this as a fact the reality is that

for one reason or the other these two games
have the most tremendously high CPU usage

I have seen on any game I have tested on this
channel, ever...

Especially when you consider this is a single
player game we are talking about.

Odyssey is the best performing of the two
on this regard, so it seemed like a great
place to start.

I disabled some effects and dropped the internal
resolution to tremendous levels using the
tweaks from my video on this game.

This was to make sure the GPU was working
and little as possible and framerate was limited
by the CPU.
I then ran the game's benchmark.
The result was better than expected,

a 52 average with some bad drops but otherwise
entirely within playable parameters.

Honestly, this is way better than I expected
by a wide margin.

Rise the settings to regular low and 1080
with an 80% scaler and this is yet another

case of a game that looks ok in low settings
and is perfectly playable with this low budget
setup.
The big offender on this regard is Origin.
Oh boy does the CPU struggle on this one.

I once again dropped the Internal Resolution
using the tweaks on its own video and it is
a stuterry mess.

The lack of CPU power causes the game to constantly
freeze.

Thankfully, this motherboard supports Overclocking
and this is a beefy air cooler... so let's
talk about that!

One of the advantages of old hardware is that
if you are lucky you can also find them on

the motherboard that supports overclocking,
thus unlocking the potential for improvements
if you have a decent cooler and decent PSU.

On this case, I was easily able to increase
to 3.5 Genehertz with little change in the

voltage and acceptable temperature and while
that does not completely remove the stuttering
it does significantly reduce it.

A new pass of the benchmark, this time on
regular lowest settings and 1080 resolution

at 80% resolution scale which does not look
bad at all runs perfectly if limited to something
like 30 fps, might even risk 40.

Battlefield V does also see a significant
improvement.

Not as dramatic as before, but still a significant
upgrade were it counts.

So while the results are pretty great, it
is important to keep in mind the limits of
this approach.

If down the line you want to get closer to
perfect 60 fps on some of these games, there
is very little you can actually do.

You can hunt for even better older CPUs for
the same socket which can be a challenge or

invest in better cooling for an Overclock,
but if your device to move to a newer CPU

you might have to change the entire motherboard
just for that, and sometimes the RAM if you
are moving to DDR4.

Still, given the results and the fact the
whole motherboard, CPU and RAM was the less

than the price of a single Athlon 200GE this
is a valid strategy if you must get gaming

now for the smallest budget possible if your
local market for used parts is good enough
to find deals like these.

Turns out there is still plenty of life for
these old components.

Now if you use something like to create your
new budget PC and you are in the process of

installing all the requisite software like
the browser and bazillion game launchers we

must all have, there is one other program
you should consider.

recycled passwords and someone used this to

enter my twitter account and did some mayor
damage.
I have told this story before.
